*Update* So now i am 20 hours into Binding of Isaac Rebirth and it´s just getting better. I love the art style and music, i never turned it off because it fits in so well. The coolest thing is, that when you find an item and have no clue what it could be and after trying some things out you finally recognize the power of it. For example   MOM´s Knive with Quad-Shot  . Just do it if you get the chance! ---- After playing this game for only 6 hours (only because if you know the first one, you know that 6 hours are nothing in this game), i already know that this is a masterpiece. The Sound is epic and creates the right atmo. The Gamplay is perfect. I control everything with my keyboard and i couldn´t find a lot of issues. Just in a few cases i stopped shooting tears. Maybe it needs a little fix there but nothing dramatic. The Items are awesome. If you wanna see whats possible with the right combo and you can´t wait just play the first few challanges and you get some ideas.  I think that this will be my indi game of the year.   So should you buy it or not?   Well if you can answere the following questions with yes, go and give Edmund McMillen his well deserved money. It isn´t expensive and you get a lot for the money you spend on it.... A lot! We need more of these games.   Did you play the first one and did you enjoy it?   Do you like roguelike games? Binding of Isaac is a Rougue Like, randomly generator, baby in a basement, twin stick shooter in a sense? I'm not yet an expert of game criteria or critique, but it's like zelda if it was less mature and more messed up. But ultimately better in my opinion.  I fell in love with the first binding of isaac because of it's difficulty and it's possibility, and that's why I love it's sequel as well, Rebirth. The game does what the first game set out to do better, and more fully. They have plenty of new items, room layouts, bosses, secrets, etc. etc.  Talking about secrets, I have to quickly mentioned this games developers put in a full fledged puzzle inside their game designed to help the community work together in order to figure it out. I won't spoiler anything, even though everyone knows about the secret by now, but I must give credit to this masterful way in which these developers designed this puzzle. In the game you have plenty of runs in which you die over, and over again. Yet the developers put in items, which when held upon death would unlock a little puzzle piece subtly in the death screen. Over a course a time, dedication, and communication between the community, hundreds of runs from thousands of players would have eventually led to the completetion of the puzzle which would've been a monumentous occasion not only to the delight of the community, but the developers as well I'm sure. Yet due to datamining and just down right scumminess the secret was revealed just as the community was learning how to solve the puzzle. It truly is sad and I agree with what one of the developers said on the matter. 'These data miners ruined something. It's like taking a gourmet steak and eating it whole in one bite.' I just want to apologize to the developers more than anything, cause I for one would've loved to have participated in this little treasure hunt. Love you guys and thanks for making such a cool idea, and sorry it was crushed.  Anyway back to the actualy game now that I'm done with my rant. It plays very similarlily to the first game since I was able to jump into my first run and win the whole thing as if I was a veteran of the game since technically I was with the first game.   If you are a long time fan of the original Binding Of Isaac or just like twin stick shooter, strange, rouge like games then this is right up your alley. Honestly if you are this late to the party you should already know this by now. I'm just writing this review out of respect and love for the game. I can't just pour 500 hours of my life into a franchise and not give back to it like that. Edmund McMuffin, you dun good.

What a fun game. It's a remake of an older game from about 2011 called, you guessed it, The Binding of Isaac. It's a massive refurbishment to it's parent. Adding newer graphics, enemies, enemies, sound effects, music, etc. The addition of all these items of course adds a large amount of play time and difficulty. You can pour hours into this game and will still have a while longer to play (I mean, if you're a completionist.) Not to mention that this game adds in seperate accounts and save data, meaning if you need to get off of the application, you could just save and quit. This game does not skimp on secrets either. Loads of easter eggs, as far as the pixel-style, tear-chuckin' eye can see. Just, for the rooms that shape a crescent, bomb the middles of the wall nearest to the center. It's a seeeeecret. Of all the games I just play for fun, this one is high up in my list. This game is filled with replyability, content, and not to mention humor. The items you collect usually have clever, and crude humor alike. But, the jokes do tend to be a bit... controversial, and by that I mean it kind of pokes fun at christianity. Having all of the religous junk, it struck down it's possibility of bieng on the WiiU, it almost was, but Nintendo had to not have it cuza the religion stuff. I'm not one to complain, under it's kind of messed up texture it's a very fun, addictive game. I've got 69 hours on record and counting. If you're planning on buying, then get ready to ragequit your figurative pants off.

Although the original BoI was pretty good, it was plagued by compatibility issues and a laggy framerate due to its flash base. Another thing the flash base brought to the table was easily deletable save files.  Luckily, Nicalis decided to take this game, put it through their 'Nicalis machine', and give it back to us shiny and new, with tons of new abilities, items, rooms, characters and many other things. The game is polished very well, and although people complain about the art style, the 16 bit Isaac looks stunning in the 3D world, and the game runs at a solid 60 fps on most computers due to its optimisation.  Nicalis took a great game plagued by disappointing aspects, and gave it back to us shiny and new, ready for us to finish again and again and again.

By Louisa Carter  Sharethis recipe  Add to favourites Send to mobile Shopping list Print recipe Ingredients 135g/4¾oz plain flour 1 tsp baking powder ½ tsp salt 2 tbsp caster sugar 130ml/4½fl oz milk 1 large egg, lightly beaten 2 tbsp melted butter (allowed to cool slightly) or olive oil, plus extra for cooking  Fluffy American pancakes  Preparation time less than 30 mins Cooking time less than 10 mins Serves Serves 4-6 Dietary   Vegetarian These pancakes are light and fluffy and great for a weekend brunch. Try adding a large handful of fresh blueberries to the batter before cooking.  Read our guide to supercharging your pancakes.   By Louisa Carter  Sharethis recipe  Add to favourites Send to mobile Shopping list Print recipe Ingredients 135g/4¾oz plain flour 1 tsp baking powder ½ tsp salt 2 tbsp caster sugar 130ml/4½fl oz milk 1 large egg, lightly beaten 2 tbsp melted butter (allowed to cool slightly) or olive oil, plus extra for cooking To serve Maple syrup Butter  Recipe tips Method Sift the flour, baking powder, salt and caster sugar into a large bowl. In a separate bowl or jug, lightly whisk together the milk and egg, then whisk in the melted butter. Pour the milk mixture into the flour mixture and, using a fork, beat until you have a smooth batter. Any lumps will soon disappear with a little mixing. Let the batter stand for a few minutes. Heat a non-stick frying pan over a medium heat and add a knob of butter. When it's melted, add a ladle of batter (or two if your frying pan is big enough to cook two pancakes at the same time). It will seem very thick but this is how it should be. Wait until the top of the pancake begins to bubble, then turn it over and cook until both sides are golden brown and the pancake has risen to about 1cm (½in) thick. Repeat until all the batter is used up. You can keep the pancakes warm in a low oven, but they taste best fresh out the pan. Serve with lashings of real maple syrup and extra butter if you like.

If you liked The Binding of Isaac, roguelikes, or the old school Zelda games, then you will love The Binding of Isaac: Rebirth. This remake takes the extraordinary level of variety of the original Binding of Isaac to a whole new level, with new bosses, new items, new characters, and countless new rooms, including larger rooms to provide new kinds of challenges. Rebirth also fixes many of the bad 'bugs' from the original game, allowing many items to interact in new and exciting ways (just try Brimstone with Tammy's Head and you'll see what I mean), while retaining some of the 'good bugs,' such as the compass effect occasionally occuring with the Liberty Cap trinket.   The game also introduces several useful features, such as multiple files, which would be nice in a home with multiple users who don't want to share, and the ability to resume the last game, if it was exited through the menu, helping in those cases when you get a good run but don't have the time to finishe immediately. The addition of easily customizable controls also allows you to get a comfortable setup for yourself, and fullscreen mode finally exists! There are also a few other options- notably hitting tab (or whatever you set it to) toggles a larger map with a timer of the current playthrough - but I think these are by far the most worthwhile. There's also a local co-op mode which seems interesting, but I have yet to try it.   And I nearly forgot, the music! Rebirth has a beautiful and fittingly dark soundtrack which well accents the gameplay, with the additional improvement of the music adjusting to the current room - so if the room is slowed or sped up, the music will be as well. If there are a lot of enemies, additional instrumentation may join in. It's a nice touch which gives the game some polish.  In summary, if it's on sale, buy it! If it's not on sale, still buy it unless you think you'll hate it! (In which case I don't know why you're looking at these reviews, but you could try the cheaper original Binding of Isaac to see how it suits you.) It's well worth the investment!

The Binding of Isaac: Rebirth is a fantastic sequel to a also fantastic game. The meat of this game comes with the huge amount of replayability; unlockable bosses, hundreds of items, many unlockable items and secrets.  Although difficult, The Binding of Isaac: Rebirth is a highly recommended rogue-like game. I've hardly seen anybody who doesn't like it, but they exist... They just, hide under a rock or something, I dunno. They're rare, okay?  Anyway, about the reasons this game will earn at least a 8/10 as the final verdict: First off, the enemies.  There are many, many enemies in this game. Some are damn annoying, but even though they're annoying you have to give it to the designers: They're well made and have cool weaknesses to defeat.   Second off: The combat system. At first it seems very basic; you shoot tears in a direction, either up, down, left or right. But actually, as you begin to start getting upgrades, it will change more complicated. Heck, there's one item that makes you shoot SCYTHES instead of tears, how cool is that?  Third off: Replayability. If you want replayability, gosh does this game have it. You will have way over 1000 runs, mostly unique. Also as you play on and defeat bosses, you'll unlock new levels and bosses which then let you unlock more items depending on which character you killed which boss with. For example:  Character A defeats Boss B, Character A unlocks Book of Anguish.  However, when Character B defeats Boss B, Character B unlocks Double Shot instead of Book of Anguish which Character A would have unlocked if they had defeated Boss B instead. See? Two completely different items.  Fourth of all: The smoothness and mobility of this game is amazing. You can map all your controls, there's gamepad support, there's a 'flash filter' and don't quote me on this but seeing as all the teasers Edmund and the crew have been giving out, it may come out on many consoles.  BUT PLEASE TAKE IN NOTE: You cannot use your mouse to shoot tears anymore, which is quite a bummer and is actually a flaw. If this gets fixed and either I notice it or someone tells me, I'll remove this section from the review.  Fifth: It has good graphics. It may look like just a pixel game, which it kind of is, but actually there's a lot of shaders, etc in the game.  Overall this is a great game and has hardly any flaws in my opinion. It's just... Amazing.  The final verdict is a 9/10. Why do I keep reviewing such amazing games? Well, I highly recommed this game. You will love it.

After putting 90+ hours into the original Binding of Isaac, I was hesitant to buy rebirth. Rebirth exceeded everything that I expected. The music, the characters, the items, and the trinkets have all been refreshed nicely. I still find myself restarting on a new run just like the original. I especially enjoy the bigger dungeon rooms, having to work with strategically placed abundent enemies gives me a pretty awesome feeling clearing a room. Everything is animated beautifully and everything seems to be less 'floaty' and more solid and cohesive. Brilliant coding and Edmund's dedication to this game have brought it up to 'Super Meat Boy' standards. Precise controls and solid gameplay.

Dustforce truly is a work of art. I don't mean that lightly. The way it's animated plus its music gives it that title in my book. I can find myself playing one level for an hour, maybe even hours at a time. The frustration of losing levels is filled with relaxation and calmness because of the ambient music. The way the levels are crafted is truly mindblowing. They had a system in which you had to perfect a level to earn a key, and you would use that key to earn more levels. In layman's terms, to earn more levels, you had to perfect current levels. They ditched that and added an XP system in which you gain more XP to earn a key the more levels you play and perfect. I'm very glad they added this system and was skeptical about buying it. But now that I did buy it, I do not regret it even for a second. One thing I really love about this game is how you don't have to unlock base levels. In a sense, this game is open world. That sense is that many levels are available to you, and you can choose whether you want to advance into more challenging levels, or stay where you're at. To get an S in completion, you have to sweep up EVERY leaf, and to get an S in Finesse, you have to maintain your combo throughout an entire level.   Another thing I absolutely enjoy about Dustforce is its expasive community. There are lots of Community Workshop maps for you to sharpen your skills on, and lots of people who can set a good example. I'm sure most of the people who get best times on all the levels have a Youtube channel, so you can probably catch them there. The community may or not be active, but it sure is good and friendly.  Overall, in terms of gameplay, music, artstyle, animation, and difficulty (it's not an easy game, but it's not that hard of a game either. It just depends on how much you want to play it), I rate this game:  10/10 BUY THIS GAME.

Rebirth takes original Binding of Isaac and fixes most everything that was wrong with it.   If you have played the original Isaac and enjoyed it, just buy this already as this is just plain and simple better in every way (graphic preferences aside). This also runs much, much better than original due to not being flash game. So far I haven't had a single FPS drop even when having some absolutely crazy stuff happening.  If not, then let me explain. In Binding of Isaac: Rebirth you play as Isaac roaming through randomly generated dungeon levels crying projectile tears on different kind of abomination enemies while collecting crazy items which make you cry more, or different tears. Sounds fun, right? Well that's because it is.   By the basic definition this game is like many other roguelite games; you roam dungeon killing enemies and collecting items trying to reach the final boss. but what makes Rebirth so different are the solid 'twin stick' shooting mechanics and countless item combinations you find during the game which can completely change the way you have to play. This is what makes this game so replayable and interesting as it really spices up the fighting and can bring some ridiculous twists to gameplay.  This game is hard. This game is frustrating sometimes. But it most definitely is rewarding and fun. There are some 400+ items in the game (many are behind unlocks) and 11 characters to play as. Multiple floors, multiple endings (which also are behind unlocks). There's a lot to do if you plan to 100% this and lot of fun to be had doing so.  Not much to be said about the graphics, it's pixel art. Game has some cool effects though and it doesn't look too retro. Sounds divide opinions, some think original had better soundtrack and I somewhat agree.  I 100% recommend getting Rebirth if you enjoy any roguelikes at all.

WHAT IS REBIRTH? : An enhanced remake of Wrath of the Lamb with every bit of content and mechanic expended further and even in new directions. This game is great but not perfect.  THE BAD:  ~ The new music for most part is not as memorable as in the original. It's not bad in any mean but for most part not as good. ~ No mouse control at the menus at all. Also if you have a x360 controller it won't tell you want key do what on the first floor and the config screen shows all up wrong. ~ Some of the graphics are just overwhelmingly inferior to the flash version. Pixel-art or not, the troll bomb doesn't look like a trollface. Some of the changes are just a matter of taste but I don't dig all of the pixel art in this game and I love pixel art. ~ The minimap is useless because you can barely see the icons and you can't see the whole floor like in the previous game. A face that forces you to walk the floor to see further in the minimap for rooms you've been to. ~ There is only 1 resolution for the game. May look really bad (as intended to look like a SNES game) on big monitors. It's more a matter of taste but still... if the resolution was higher then the trollface would look like one. ~ The new sounds. especially Mom's, are just bad. Simply as that. The only good sfx are the re-used ones from WotL. ~ If you liked the gore of the first game then this one turns the dial to 11. Which is good. The bad part is with so many puddles of blood and crawling larvas on the floor (especially in dark rooms) it's hard to tell where you can walk. With practice it's not so bad but it's still bad for new players.  THE GOOD: You can read all of it in the game description. I'll just sum it as 'rainbow ♥♥♥♥'. Because it's a new type of ♥♥♥♥ on the floor you can find in the game. Really.  BOTTOM LINE: If you finished WotL then you probably have this game so why are you reading this? New to the game/genre? You may hate this because the game is not easy. Go play the demo of Bind of Isaac (the first game) to see what it's like. If you liked it then know that the demo is a tiny fraction of this game and you're up for a treat.  IS IT WORTH THEM 15$? : If you like the first game then YES. See bad points above because they may furiate you. If you don't like to spend those dollars wait for it to be on xmas sale or in Humble/Stars Bundle or Indie Gala. Can't say it's not worth a buy at any price. Should be 10$ for most time which is more than fair for the amount of time you can invest in this game.

So, Rebirth. Well the game lives up to the title. It is a 'rebirth' for The Binding Of Isaac.  It adds many new items and synergies as well as enemies and bosses. The graphics are fine but they are not for everyone. The music is fantastic and makes every single floor feel different. Having many new synergies makes every run feel interesting and new.   The changes to old bosses make them tougher but still similar to their old selves. Items that were useless before have gotten better with or without the new synergies. The newcharacter Azazel is easier for new players to use if they struggle with learning the game If you didn't get it at this point, I love Rebirth.  But just because I love it does not mean I don't see some flaws.  For example, Bugs. There are many of these. Some of them have already been fixed but some people still cannot play the game. Some of them make the game completely unplayable. Luckily I have experienced few of these.  Also some of the rooms feel a bit 'cheap' as they have a lot of space but only if you have the ability to fly.  This game will be harder to get into for those who have played many hours of the original. Many of the new bosses have combinations of attacks from old bosses or completely new attacks that take getting used to.  All in all it's a pretty good game. Is it perfect? No. But it's a good game. and it's fun. That's enough for me.

As someone with 400+ hours and all the unlocks for the base game and the DLC expansion, here's a basic rundown of what the game is  25% of runs are gonna be difficult ones where you're underpowered The rest are gonna be broken as ♥♥♥♥ overpowered runs The thing about those OP runs is that they really are boring and take all the challenge away from the game, but that's what the devs intended when they made the different item synergies  Also, it's completely based around unlocking things 'B-but Ellark y-you can still p-play for fun r-r-right???' It's not really fun playing Rebirth over and over without any new unlocked items or floors for you to discover  Also, 2 of the characters (1 is in the DLC, the DLC also has an unlock which makes the non-DLC easier) are complete utter bull-♥♥♥♥ing-♥♥♥♥   1 insta dies from everything, the other I wont spoil  TLDR if you're a complete slug: Boring game based completely around unlocks with ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t characters and OP runs which are not fun, due to them taking any challenge out of the game  Edit: Forgot to mention that some items are automatic run-winners or automatic picks while some can be classified as 'hot garbage'. All items should be equal in a game with 400+ of them, in my opinion  6/10, get it if you're patient and don't like challenge

New companions, new abilites, detailed backgrounds and lights, playing coop with your friends... Sure, improvements are always great. But since everyone seems to like The Binding of Isaac Rebirth and I'm completely repelled by it everytime I play, I feel the urge to write down why I still prefer the old Isaac to the new one.  -Animations are worse. They're still and stiff, not even close to lively. -With the worse animations and artworks, cutscenes are not cool as the other one either. As I said, too stiff. (Not talking about the one when you beat Mother, it is an improvement, but you have to dealwith most of the game to see it only once... Seriously...) -Voices. Period. I loved how those bloated guys cry, the sound Isaac did when he died... -Where is all the good music? I admit, there are a few tracks that I've liked in the new one but... Seriously, where did those go? They were brilliant! Especially in the Depths/Necropolis. I'd hoped there'd me reworks of those but instead I found an atmosphere sound and emptiness. -This may count in 'Voices' but... How come Isaac's mother sounds like a 30 year old MILF? -With the new map, you cannot see any items-enemies-etc. at the top right corner of the room. -New graphics. Everyone's hyped about how HD it can be and all but I can't understand how easily you've forgotten the unique style of the original Isaac and how sweet they were. The new one's also stiff and un-living. They could still be HD and pixelish 8-bit style, keeping the original sweetness and liveliness. I too, am a fan of pixel art and 8bit style but this is NOT how you do this, believe me. -So many graphical mistakes... Ever realized wooden spoon's visual effect appears also on the hair? I was only on the skin before, like properly. Duh. ♥♥♥♥♥ of babylon is not even close to what it used to be with broken horns. -There is a thing written in even the worst quality pixel art tutorial: CLEAN UP THE LINEART! I can see you missed this one because everything looks so rushed, dirty and obviously paid no attention. -In the shiny-colorful cutscene's chest's perspective is so wrong it made my eyes hurt. -Too much poop-pee-vomit. It's okay to a point but after a while it stops being funny but gets boring. The old Isaac had the perfect balance for it. Poop, here's a cute sound for it. And after a while you get rolling guts and twisted nipples and screaming babies with carved out eyes. This way it was more horror-istic, now it looks like a preschooler quality humor. -Also, everything sounds a fart-vomit-etc. Meh. -Gut's rolling animation is COMPLETELY WRONG sometimes. They roll BACKWARDS. Couldn't you just mirror the image when they were rolling to the opposite direction? I can't believe you did this mistake... -Though the new backgrounds and light effects are REALLY GOOD, since every other thing is a fallback, it's not user friendly. You can't make out the flies and blood drops flying to you while fighting five enemies because they're not even visible in that background.  Reminder: These are only MY opinions. If you've liked it, fine, good for you, go and have fun, I'm happy for you. But I only wanted to see if anyone else feels like I do.  I may still recommend it because it's still good, especially if you haven't played the old one. Still a unique experience in all those shoot-and-kill games. But, yeah, I still prefer the old one.

The problem with the game is in the little and often, small problems everywhere that just seem to just make the game feel worse overall:  There are more enemies, but they feel poorly designed, and just derivitive of each other. The only one that really feels outright different are the wall spiders, and that's because it's doing something mechanically different to any other enemy in the game, but it's still a damn spider. Many of these new enemies use the same sort of AI that charge at the player character at tight angles, leaving yourself taking damage quite often. The original was less like this, and was more about avoiding damage alltogether than just mitigating it and picking up a health container that seem in an almost limitless supply.  There are more items; but many of these new items serve very little purpose, I guess the same could be said of the previous items, but many of them feel out of place, both in name and in use. The majority of these new items outright tell you what they do, the previous game mostly just dropped hints, you had to more or less discover for yourself what certain items did and that was a part of the experience. The old items had significance, in a subtle lore perspective, but now we're getting to the point where Isaac has 4 different dead pets of different species and they all make him very sad in ever more objectively useless ways.  There is a new soundtrack; but it feels very hollow, i've played the game for 7 hours and I found myself turning off the music before the first 2. It's mostly generic guitars and brooding chords that honestly, don't stack up to the original's soundtrack and it's fantastic atmosphere creation.  It is a new engine with a new style, but the art style is now twisted into the curse and cliche of the 'retro indie', where there has to be jagged edges and PIXELS.  I have yet to try the co-op as of yet, and probably will not, but I appreciate how it might be a thing some people may enjoy.  I dislike the fact that you cannot use the mouse in conjunction with the keyboard,(or at all honestly, not even for navigating the menus) especially when there are a few items that would infact benefit from it, I would say that using wasd and the arrow keys in contradicting patterns is not something I can handle.  I strongly dislike how the tutorial square didn't infact show the default keybinds for the game. This seems like a very small issue, but given that I actually had trouble finding which key was the 'drop bomb' key, I think it's worth mentioning. For some reason, despite it being bound to both the q and shift key in the original, and how you can bind multiple keys to the same action in rebirth, it didn't cross the developers' minds to echo the previous game and use a double keybind.  Also, once in game, you cannot check the keybinds in the options menu, god forbid if you change a key before you start playing the game and have to quit to change it, or you spend 5 minutes pressing random keys on the keyboard because once in game you can't even look at the controls.  Although I am 'recommending' this game, it is certainly not flawless, and I would actually recommend the original game with it's awful flash engine over rebirth, to newcomers of this 'series'.

This game gets alot of praise and for good reasons, but the same thing urks me about this game that the original did. Its 90% luck based. The fun of this game is seeing how far you can get with what you have, but luck will have it that you have little. Theres many scenarios where you must choose how to spend an item, and in general, make do with what you get. Experimenting with all the different items is alot of fun.  But at the end of the day, you cant win without stat increases. If you only get bad pill spawns or active after active after active items, you can only make it so far without some sort of sheilding or durability. Once you know what all the items do and which characters are the best, you start to notice that some items are better off just not taking, or the game will just not give you any resources like keys or bombs, and only give you gold and stone chests. Then you start to instantly quit and spawn a new dungeon until you get something you like.  But it doesnt matter if you try over and over and over to get a good start or just get fun items, its entirely luck based. I honestly cant say whether or not anyone will like this game because their experience can be fortunate one, or the game just gives you bad items or starves you at every turn, and you just wont complete the game until you restart countless times. I did not have often good games, so i had a negative experience overall, but you not might. maybe. maybe not.

Compared to the previous game, rebirth offers a hilariously bad soundtrack, too many overpowered items, and just not enough new content to make it worth the $15 price tag. Anyone new to the isaac series should purchase the original.

90 hours in, I think I'm finally ready to review Rebirth. TL;DR - if you don't mind the religious overtones and iconography, there is no reason not to own this game.  I never got into the original Isaac for a few reasons, Flash chief among them. But with Rebirth's new engine I decided it was time to give it another go. For those unfamiliar with The Binding of Isaac, it is a top-down, permadeath dungeon crawler with randomized layouts and powerups. From far away, you could mistake it for a dungeon from the original Legend of Zelda in both gameplay and UI, and you wouldn't be entirely wrong. If you married the gameplay and aesthetic of Legend of Zelda with the random generation, item variety and permadeath from the Rogue-like genre, you get Isaac.  Each run of Isaac is unique: The items, monsters, bosses, floor layouts, curses and more all change with each playthrough. Heck, there are special 'dice rooms' which can change the whole playthrough on the fly.  The game excels at providing the carrot on a stick needed to keep bringing the player back for another go. As the 170+ achievements hint, there are quite a few unlockables. Each run can take 30-90 minutes, and you are generally rewarded for every run completed so long as you've done something you hadn't yet done before. For example, there are several characters unlocked at the beginning of the game, each of which unlocks something once its first run is complete. There are many different bosses you can face at the end of each floor, many of which also unlock something when first defeated.  Not all is well, unfortunately. Given the dozens (hundreds?) of items and pickups in the game, it can be difficult to remember what effects any given item has, and the in-game descriptions are generally lacking. You can easily find yourself regretting an item you've picked up, assuming you can even figure out what it did. There is a fair amount of ambiguity in the game, which ultimately steers players towards a wiki. This does further disservice to the game, as spoilers regarding unlocked content can sap much of the enjoyment of discovery.  The game also has deep, overarching religious themes and iconography, with biblical stories overtly defining much of the game. This may be off-putting if you are an easily offendable follower of the Abrahamic religions, but is otherwise innocuous and quickly forgotten.  Ultimately, The Binding of Isaac: Rebirth is an enjoyable game with long-lasting replayability. The dollar-per-hour of entertainment ratio of this game ranks among the highest in my library, and I'm nowhere near done with it.

Disclaimer: I was not too huge on The Binding of Isaac. I don't hate it, by any means, I just didn't really get into it. It's good. It's really, really good. I think this is already one of my favorite games of all time.

Absolutely excelent Rouge Style game. Improves on the original in every way with new items, monsters, bosses, floors, and characters, while keeping all the content from the previous edition of the game and its expansion. Highly addictive and extremely replayable with challenge runs and a hardcore mode for those who want an even more satisfying experience.  Lag caused by too many on screen enemies from the old edition is completely fixed. You can have the screen absolutely full of items or enemies and not experience a loss of a single frame.   If you haven't played The Binding of Isaac before, definately skip the previous version and pick this up. If you played the previous edition and enjoyed it, I would still recomend Rebirth. The additional content and new engine make the game play like new.

I was trying to describe this game to a friend and realized that I had, essentially, written a review of it. I am checking 'Yes' for this game primarily because there is nowhere I can check 'Hell, yes!' You really, really need to play Binding of Isaac: Rebirth. It's a blood, urine, and feces soaked nightmare of blasphemy, gore, and ethics in games journalism. Like a video game based on the high school notebook cover of that smelly kid with aspbergers who liked Slayer a lot. Or, to put it another way, BoI:R is what my mom was picturing in her mind when she was ranting about video games being satanic when I was a kid playing NES.

After 85 hours its finally time for me to write my review, first of all i would like to start of by saying that i played the original game and for that i review this game from what i think about it compared to the original Binding of Isaac. Binding of Isaac: Rebirth, have alot of new items, including 16 new bosses, 4 new characters and alot of new rooms to explore. Really Recommend it 9/10  Now it's time for the more advanced stuff! First of all Pros and Cons.  Pros - The Game has very nice new lightning effect. - There are now a total of 7 curses including Curse of the blind Curse of the lost Curse of darkness Curse of the maze Curse of the lost Curse of the labyrinth - There are 3 new characters Azazel Lazarus Eden (Secret one im not going to spoil) - You can now exit the game without ending the run. - Lots of replayability. - Nice new pixel graphics that look alot better then the original.  Cons - The music is good, but not good enough compared to the original. - There are alot of terrible items that can ruin your run completley.  Anyway, the game is really good.      Go buy it.

(Note: I've put more time into the PS4 version than Steam) Rebirth is a direct improvement in almost every single way. The game runs smoothly at all times, looks great (especially the little details in rooms), and added about a thousand new things. Inputting seeds allows you and a friend to play the same levels and compete, and Co-op lets you tackle the game together. The one major gripe I have is the blandness of the soundtrack. The loops sound like they're about fifteen seconds long and are more ambient noise than music. I'd love for Danny B to allow the devs to add his original music as an alternative or something, as the original game is one of the few on my Steam list that doesn't have the music muted. Another minor issue is how different the ending cutscenes look compared to the game itself and the other cutscenes (intro/credits/epilogue). It's somewhat jarring, but they admittedly do look nice.  8.5/10, Strongly reccomend for the price

For context, the Binding of Isaac: Rebirth, is a remake of The Binding of Isaac and it's expansion, The Wrath of the Lamb, in a new engine while adding almost double the content. Mechanically speaking, it's a top down bullet hell type game with RPG elements such as health, keys, coins, and bombs. Furthermore, you utilize items that alter the game in various ways, such as one that makes your 'tears,' or bullets, orbit around your head. As a rogue-like, death is permanent (unless you get an extra life) and that means once you lose all health you have to restart with a new run.   While I have sunk very few hours into the 2011 predecessor, The Binding of Isaac: Rebirth proves to be an amazingly fun and complex game. It's mechanics are punishing (I find it harder than it's previous iteration), the charm in its dark, disgusting aesthitic, and the immense feeling of satisfaction everytime you complete a challenge or kill a boss keep you coming back for more.  Furthermore, the replayibility is essentially infinite, with almost 350 items that have been coded to always synergise in some way, and the procedurally generated levels mean you're always excited to learn what's behind that locked door. It encourages a curiosity that pushes you to gamble, to take a pill that could potentially end your run, and to maximize your resources to find new and unique combinations of items to defeat your foes.  That being said, there are still a few flaws with this game. I find the movment initially difficult to adapt to. To me, at least, there seems to be a moment to your character's movment that means you can't stop on a dime. This takes some adjustment, and if you aren't paying attention it can result in you stepping on hazardous obstacles like spikes. The music is not as stellar as the first. While I, personally, enjoy this track more, the sounds can be repetitve to the point of annoyance, particularly in the basement. Finally, the game provides too little information about items and mechanics. While this is part of the discovery, it can sometimes take several runs to divine how a specific item operates. Given the random nature of the game, these items appear inconsistently and thus it can take a week for even the most dedicated player to investigate the purpose of an item unless you go online and search.  Overally I give this game a 9/10, and I can assure you that I will be playing it for years to come. A few minor gripes can detract from the experience, but for a price of $15 I gurantee you will get your money's worth.

The Binding of Isaac: Rebirth is the update to one of the best indie title ever made. Its creator, Edmund Mcmillen, has one of the most intriguing interest with religion and he shares it with us in a way that makes this game's story one of the most interesting ever.  Unlockables, unlockables and unlockables. Hundreds of items, ennemies and bosses. Countless amounts of possible runs, infinite hours of gameplay, and challenges that will have you pull your hair out of every pore. The more you play, the better you get. The learning curve is insanely steep, unless you have played the first one before.  The second installment of TBoI allows you to play with a controller and in co-op mode. The engine used to make this game surpasses flash in every way, which means very little bugs, better graphics, and FULLSCREEN RESOLUTIONS! Don't get discouraged after a few runs, cause you will get better and you will learn everything you have to know within the game.  I recommend this game to any fan of roguelikes and indie titles. One indie to rule them all!  -------------------------------------------------------------- Single Player: 10/10 Random events, very addictive, funny, and the theme is awesome Multiplayer: 7/10 Co-op mode is though but it is there, which is all that matters really Graphics: 9/10 Pixel art is fine, McMillen's art is as awesome and gross as ever Community: 9/10 Streamers, nice wiki and many videos --------------------------------------------------------------

Pros: -Runs very well on most specs. -There are fewer straight up 'bad' items in Rebirth -The music for the basement levels are amazing -The dev team clearly wanted this game to be the best it could be with the new engine, which runs 3x more smoothly than the original, as well as patches put out to fix bugs and balance issues that occur. -New characters can give you a challenge or an easier time depending on who you choose.  Cons: -Music after basement level is pretty uninspired -Those ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ed bone-tossing skeletons

The Binding of Isaac: Rebirth is a must buy for anyone that loves a good challenge in their games. After your mother accepts an outrageous request from God, telling her to sacrifice her own son to prove that she truely loves him, Isaac escapes deep down below to the depths of this very hostile basement. The basement itself is randomly generated and so are the enemies that inhabit the rooms, this adds to the replayability tremendously. The basement is made up of various rooms that can either suprise you, by throwing a large amount of creatures in them, or disappoint you as some of the rooms that i've discovered bare only piles of feces. Some doors lead to very exciting rooms though, giving you unique items that change the way you play the game and change Isaac's appearance as you combine all these different treasures to your arsenal. Each item that you pick up has it's own incredible effect on you, from being nothing but a floating head to avoid spikes below, to homing tears and lazer beams, but of course if you've aready played the original game then you knew all of this. What does The Binding of Isaac: Rebirth do to deserve a remake you ask? Well there is a number of changes this game does to further drive your addiction to the point where you just accept your defeat and play the entire day away. First off, the graphics and sound have been completly remade and it nails these elements perfectly although every now and then I've experienced random drops in frame rate that leads to loosing a couple hearts in a chaotic battle. The soundtrack has been remade and you won't hear the marvelous ambient McMillen songs like before but overall they'yre appropriate for each basement you enter, adding a dark grimy feel to each song. You will notice the sound difference as enemies sound clearer then ever before and at times I tilted my head like, 'what the f**k was that?' as most of the enemies we've come to love/hate have their voices changed to a different growl or yelp. The basement has experienced quite a few changes as well, some rooms can change in size which allows for more enemies to spawn in and more room to avoid them as well. The number of power up items from the last game as well as all the combinations you can have with all of them has drastically been enhanced and makes for very exciting gameplay. The gameplay has stayed the same from the original and feels right at home. It's like getting a new system for your home and setting the old one a little to the side, You'll still be able to experience the amazing classics that old system had to offer but now you can experience more new and improved content as well. The Binding of Isaac: Rebirth is truely what all the fans of the orignal have asked for. There is a new HARD difficulty that I'm sure all the experienced players can jump right into and for newcomers is a perfect insentive to strive further and up your skill level to be able to reach that difficuty in the near future. There is also Local Co-op which is perfect for a team run when you need a hand with reaching farther into the dungeons. There is quite a few new baddies as well with unique abilities that will puzzle you and make you laugh just the same as you figure out their methods of attacking. The Binding of Isaac: Rebirth is EXACTLY what fans of the orignal have been asking for (even if you haven't been asking, it's what you NEED) and for newcomers, this game is a must buy. Now get in there and face the dark challenges below and emerge victorious!

Binding of Isaac is a great game, due to the fun and interesting challenge it has. I have put 50+ hours into this, and I've barely scratched the surface of this. It can admittedly be a major annoyance with some enemies, but it does really add the effect that you are a tiny fleshy being that must really struggle for survival. It may sound strange, but that is a big part of the game. Not surviving, but to struggle to survive.   For a game this type, it has fantastically deep gameplay, sometimes making you choose between some of the hardest decisions you can. For example: 'Should I take this item, for the cost of my hearts, or should take this item that costs only one heart, but doesnt have the same efficiency, or should I leave, risking not being able to go back either or?'   It is also extremely satisfying with the amount of items this game, all with their own effects. It adds item exploration and you will never have the same kind of build twic. You could be the most overpowered character, or the worst piece of trash.  In all, I would recommend this game, give it an A+, and whatnot, but words are just words. In order to understand, one must play the game.

What is mankind? Who am I? What is the meaning of life? These are multifaceted existential questions that ancient and modern philosophies have yet to adequately answer. Countless philosophers have spent their lifetimes in search of answers to these questions but died before finding a suitable answer. Certainly, the philosophy of existentialism is an interesting phenomenon. The dictionary defines existentialism as a 'philosophical movement . . . centering on analysis of individual existence in an unfathomable universe and the plight of the individual who must assume ultimate responsibility for acts of free will.' Isaac, from The Binding of Isaac, explores these existential questions, seeking truth and understanding as he tries to come to grips with his father's death. In the end, Isaac proves to be an exceedingly existential character.

'The Binding of Isaac: Rebirth' is kinda like the very old 'The Legend of Zelda' game. Well, it seems to be more based off of the game 'Rogue' being called a rogue like and such. Anyhow, it contains randomly generated maps, items, and bosses making each 'run' or playthrough different and unique. Then there are the challenge modes which throw so much BS at you and are so freaking difficult you want to  A) Throw your computer out the window B) Punch someone in the face C) Yell to the top of your (monstro) lungs when you die/lose D) Try the run again UNTIL YOU BEAT IT  Also, the story of the game is highly controversial, about a somewhat demented child who experiences dillusions as he tries to escape/kill his mother, the devil, himself, the corpse of himself and many more. There are also numerous characters which are each enteraining to use (except Samson...)  It's very much satisifying to win each game, as the game itself is very challenging in most situations. But in some situations you get overpowered items such as Polyphemus, Mom's Knife, Brimstone, IPECAC and/or Tech2 and the game becomes really easy, yet still entertaining.

Cons- the downside of this game is that because it is randomly generated you never have the same experience twice meaning that you can never realy develope a true strategy or way of playing that will suite every play-thu, however this could be a pro for some people. secondly, this game is frustrating as it can be very unfair at times and is best not to be played as a stress reliever. A little warning, if you masturbate to high end graphics settings and despise pixels and everything they stand for, you are looking at the wrong game. If permadeath fills you with rage and unreasoning hate for your keyboard and mouse, you shouldn't be here. If even the slightest mention of religion makes you feel like your own belief's are being attacked, leave. Otherwise, continue on.  A run usually last around 30 minutes to begin and it eases you in slow and simple, as the levels go on it gets harder and darker but you unlock more items and more characters to experiment with. The graphics are pixel art done right and it fits the dark, dreamlike quality of the story and game, and the music and sound effects perfectly suit the gory enemies and disturbing setting.  The replayability is quite frankly endless, there are several hundred items and multiple characters with very different play styles and starting abilities. There is permadeath, but everytime you die chances are you'll have unlocked a new item or character on your playthough to try out on your next run, no run feels wasted in Isaac, because you're always seeing something new.  The story and setting has religious overtones, but it is hard to know just how much of it is in the mind of the protagonist Isaac and his own interpretation of the changes in his life. The story is very much open to interpretation, making the 'endings' very thought provoking.  For the money, this game is excellent and one of the best rogue-lites I have ever played. The Binding of Isaac: Rebirth is a very fun, dark game. Its a bit like the legend of zelda, but with its own little twist. You start off as a boy, Isaac, who lives in a religous household and god has spoken to isaac's mother and told her isaac was to be killed to show her love for god. She tries to kill isaac but he finds a hidden trapdoor and jumps into the unknown. The game is played from a top down perspective and you collect items that give certin buffs and debuff (the also change the looks of your character) and you fight evil monsters such as, decapitaded bloody bodies, evil flying skulls, spiders, and anthropomorphic poop. I gave the game a 9/10 because its fun, challanging, and the dark humor is funny to me.

Great game. Rogue-like, so it has that old-school urgency and moments of panic (although you can record the seed of a good run and try it again if you die.) The story is simple and twisted, your adversaries are cartoon nightmares...truly unsettling sometimes, purposely (I think) rendered in 16-bit 'cute' graphics. The difficulty of the game changes owing to the random setup. In any case, be prepared to die many times before you slip into your groove. The amount and variety of power-ups is astounding, and if you are lucky enough to run across items that synergize you can become unstoppable.  This is easliy my favorite game at the moment. It is completely addictive, and once you figure out what is going on there is a deep level of strategy involved. If you do decide to play this game, I suggest you download an item guide.  Easily 10/10 This is a flawless game.

I have mixed feelings about this game so far. There's enough new content that I think its worth being its own game, and I really like the new engine and better FPS. There's new and interesting level design, enemies, bosses, and items, and the technical issues that existed in the old game seem to be fixed (*cough* Brimstone *cough*). I also like the save files and new characters, not to mention controller support and local CoOp! Content wise, the game is very satisfying. It might just be me, but I also find it a good bit harder (and I haven't even tried hard mode yet) because of the unpredictability of the movements of the new enemies and because your base tears seem to be a bit weaker and slower. Whether or not this is a good thing is debateable.  My only real issues are small ones, admittedly. I am in the minority that doesn't really care for the new graphics, since even though a lot of the sprites have added detail and granularity, which is great, I feel they take away from the unique, clean look the developer's other games had. They used to really stand out, and now they've just hopped onto the pixel art bandwagon. Don't get me wrong, I really love and appreciate pixel art when its done right, but I just don't think BoI-R does it right. Pixel art doesn't have to look fuzzy and cheap, and theirs just does. Also on the topic of looks, this game is a lot more explicitly gross, gorey, and disgusting, which I don't mind *too* much, but it is a little off-putting in my opinion. Its hard to keep playing a game that gives you a continuous slight queezy feeling, though I suppose some would say that's the point of BoI. Just as a warning though, if the first game's gore made you uncomfortable, this one will probably make you sick.  I also have a few issues with the sounds. The new soundtrack is pretty good, not really as distinctive and as full of personality as the first, but not bad. What I really don't like is that they've taken some sounds out, like the placing of bombs (which can be very inconvenient if you drop one by accident, since the bomb sprite drops behind the Isaac sprite so you can't see it unless you move), and I find the sounds they used for Isaac getting hit and the ones for various enemies to be just plain grating and annoying. They took so much from the first game, I really wish they had just kept the original sound effects, especially since there wasn't anything wrong with them in the first place.  Overall I'd say this game looks and sounds like a downgrade, but it definitely doesn't play like one. I recommend it, but I feel that with the decreased aesthetic appeal on multiple fronts, I'll be a bit less inclined to play it for hours on end like I did the first game, which is a shame because one of BoI's big selling points is its ridiculous replay value. I would also like it if they had put better descriptions of what items do in-game so that I don't keep having to pause the game and look up what everything does. Still, its a good game, and, for the most part, worth the money.

The Binding of Isaac: Rebirth is nothing short of phenomenal. The vast array of items and endless rooms and layouts leaves one both baffled and delighted. Not only do these things alone bring replayability but also immense diversity in gameplay. I've been watching twitch streamers with much, much more time logged than me who still have 'never seen this before' moments, quite frequently actually. While the imagery and game content itself may be excessive and explicit depending on the taste to some, I personally found it quirky and intriguing.   I'd recommend this game to those with an open mind and chunk of patience. It can be challenging to get into but a thrill once pulled in. As stated above, a treasure trove of replayability, charming and quirky story bits. It's well worth the price for these reasons alone. It runs fine and as intended. Really no complaints or negative comments at all. As previously stated, some of the content may be controversial for some people however. If this concerns you, watch a twitch livestreamer or youtube gameplay video and decide if that is a problem for you. Other than that, buy it.

The gameplay has been optimised, new content has been added to a ridiculous degree of detail and scale, and the engine has been taken out of Flash and into Nicalis' own engine, for consistent 60fps speeds on most computers. A very hard rogue-like game. This means that you start the game, and play through the levels until you either beat the boss, or die. If you die, you can't start from where you left off, you have to start the game over from the beginning. There are many items to unlock and the replay value of this game is extremely high. I would very likely recommend this game to anyone who likes a challenge, and who isn't afraid to be a little sacreligious, as the game does have christian elements, and sometimes it can seem like the game is 'making fun' of the religion. However it may seem, the game is very well put together. This is a revamped version of The Binding of Isaac, which was made by the same guy that made Super Meat Boy.

This game is fantastic.  Its kinda hard for me to describe why I like it so much, but here goes.  I orignally played the first Binding of Isaac, and was entertained for a couple hours, but quickly got bored. With rebirth, I am still the first game I go to after 200 hours. The items and their synergies are amazing, the bosses are fantastic, the whole experience is absolutely worth every penny. Each run seems like a fresh start, but not at the expense of being boring. The runs are of decent length, and there are plenty of goals to shoot for and items to unlock to keep you interested.  The one thing I suggest is to get the dlc sooner rather than later, as it makes the game seem way more full. (however, I reccomend unlocking lost with seeds before you get the dlc, if you plan on unlocking it)  10/10 one of my favorite games of all time.

After more than 80 hours playing original The Binding of Isaac I have finally put my hands on Afterbirth and I can say that this is one of the best remake I have ever seen. I have waited until DLC release so you can imagine how overwhelming it was for me to experience so many new things. In fact it still is.   All the major improvements like:  - better performance  - less bugs - TONS of new items - advanced item integration (those 'sick combos' which were almost imposible in the original TBoI)  - new modes 'Daily Run' and 'Greed' from DLC  - new enemies and challenging bosses - seeds - etc.  and minor things that don't affect your run:  - gorgeous floor designs - atmospheric music  - ability to save your run and turn off the game - etc.  all these things and many others altogether create a beautiful nightmare that will suck you in for really long time.  Of course, Afterbirth has got many bugs, but it is only matter of time when Nicalis will fix those. They have done an amazing job so far and I don't see any reason for them to stop.   P.S. What I really would like them to do (not only me actually) is to unnerf the Azazel. I've heard so much about the OPness of this character and really wanted to try it by myself, but now he's almost unplayable.

I gotta say - best Christmas present ever. Thank you brother.  Rebirth (and Afterbirth, might I add) takes the original Binding of Isaac and does exactly what it should do. As the saying goes, if it ain't broke, don't fix it. But everything it has added has been very necessary and makes the experience even more enjoyable than the original - three save files as opposed to one, controller compatibility, more enemies, more items, more awesome - basically. The graphics and art style hasn't changed much but it's noticeable, and I like it. The pixelation and slightly darker colouring is most certainly appreciated. And the controls as a whole are a lot more comfortable. I can't return to the original now without it feeling heavier in comparison.  A job well done, and a game I will probably enjoy for weeks and months to come.

The Binding of Isaac: Rebirth is a remake of the original Binding of Isaac. So, what's different between Rebirth and the original? -New pixelated art. This is one of the best pixel art work I've ever seen. A lot of people seems to hate it and prefer the original art. But there's a filter that make the graphic look like the original. -New soundtrack. In my opinion, the new soundtrack is so much better than Danny B's. Together, the soundtrack and the graphics make a really great atmosphere. -TONS of new items, enemies, mechanics, achievements, etc. -New synergies. -Controller support. -New engine. No longer in flash.  The bad things. -Map placement. The map is really annoying and can sometimes block things, especially with the bigger maps which blocks almost half of your screen. -No mouse support. I use mouse and keyboard as the controls on the original Binding of Isaac. It's now hard for me to play without mouse, the keyboard and controller just feel off for me. But after some time, I get used to it. Still, no reason to remove the mouse controls and it would be nice if they bring it back on future updates.

Also the save and resume later feature is a huge bonus, no longer have to worry about starting a round and not being able to finish if you get a killer item set.  Would purchase time and again and highly reccomend.

Binding of Isaac is a game where you go through dark rooms, kill scary things and finally kill mom (and maybe more). After which you will have to repeat the process until you unlock EVERY SINGLE (ACHIEVEMENT) ITEM IN THE GAME. Along with new bosses and new characters (with different starting items).  It is a game that can be described as luck versus skill. Either you get a few bad items and can manage the rest or you get a lot of bad items and only your skill and perseverance stops you from restarting your run.  Every boss in the game is fun, at least the first time you beat them. A successful run should generally last an hour maybe a bit more. The random nature of the game helps make the game feel fresh and exciting at least until you memorize all the rooms.  The expansion adds a new, faster Greed mode with a final boss and a secret boss after mom's heart, both of which have the innovative ability to damage cap your tears. Also a ton of new junk and sidegrades.

**** - 4/5  Game is intensly fun with an unlimited replay value. Art is brilliantly executed and the music exceeds fanatastic. Probably the only downfall with this game - personally - is the lack of new synergies, but I hear that will be worked upon in the new update/expansion; if so then 5/5!

Pros:   Synergy - Combinations of over 200 items repeatedly provides interesting and surprising shot effects. Style - Dark and juvenile humor held together with clever satirical elements.  Gameplay - Endless RNG play.  Updates - Two years on its second iteration, Isaac is still being improved and added to periodically. Challenge - Difficulty ramping from moderate to severe, the game rewards decision making as much as skill. Auto-save - If something happens, your game isn't Lost.  Cons:  Awkward map - Never quite felt fully integrated into the core design or reached comfortable ease of use. Stability - Controller / keyboard swaps are not smooth. If your controller dies during a game, prepare to Alt-F4 and restart.   ****  Rebirth / Afterbirth is one of the very few games I can return to repeatedly, and after long absences. The game never gets old, even if you've unlocked everything, you can probably still encounter a synergy you've never seen before or have a unique run that goes extremely well or punishes you until you die. This can be a challenging game. Understanding of item interactions, uses, and limitations can help you make decisions that can lead you to turn a bad set of dice rolls into a winning game. Experience goes hand in hand with skill to turn a frustrating run into a victory. Avoiding damage and landing shots only gets you so far - finding the things you need to survive is part of what makes playing Isaac so endlessly entertaining.   The style of the game may be juvenile, but the gameplay is anything but immature. This is a complex twin-stick shooter that will demand more of your attention while punishing the unworthy.

I have 489 hours on the original game. You can see how many hours I have on this one. I'm not crazy a fan of the game's aesthetic, but I do think it's interesting and unique (and personal, from what I've seen of Edmund McMillen's interviews).  The really fun and addictive thing about it is the of arcadey gameplay and randomization. It combines the Skinner Box elements (what cool stuff will I get on the next treasure room?) with a rewarding fast gameplay. It has some bullet hell aspects, although it's not even close to stuff like Ikaruga. Oh yeah, it also borrows a lot from the top down zeldas (A Link to The Past, basically)  I uninstalled this game, because there are other games, and I recognize I have a problem. This is not my favorite game, more like my favorite drug.

Fun and challenging game which has a wide range of procedural variation that allows it to stay fresh and enjouable hundreds of hours in. No Man's Sky could have learnt quite a lot from its approach.   There's also quite a dirty satisfaction gained from getting a grossly overpowered set of items and wrecking the most powerful bosses in the game in a matter of seconds.  It has a well balanced difficulty curve that eases you into the action, and many layers that just kinda keep unfolding the more time you sink into the game. If you're a perfectionist there are a few hurdles that may make you want to cry tears of blood, some made artificially frustrating through the many grindy and unlikely attempts that have to be made.  Personally a big fan of the stylized aesthetic and themes. The story is told in a very sideways manner that you piece together, and fits with the design of the environments, enemies, items, and playable characters to comment on quite a few topics (including religion, neglect and escapism (and dead cats)).   Well worth your money if it sounds even remotely interesting. As a person who wasn't previously very much into dungeon crawlers/rouge-lite style games, this was a great introduction to the genre. Maybe hold off on the Afterbirth DLC on initial purchase, and see if the game really gells with you. It's definitely good value, but is much more of the same and isn't at all necessary for new players.

If you've somehow never heard of this game, picture the dungeoncrawling of a 2d zelda game...only more twisted. You collect items, powerups and augments to your 'tears' attack, as you make your way lower through the chambers of enemies and bosses. This roguelike cycle is but one of the many layers to this bloomin' onion. As you start to unlock new paths, characters, items, enemies, and features, you start to lose track of just how much is in this game. If you're at all on the fence, get it. You won't be disappointed.   10/10 dead baby jokes

The Binding of Isaac: Rebirth is the most addictive, entertaining, and interesting rogue-like game I have ever played. It has got the original Isaac game attributes and better complications. At first you fall in love with this game as you advance through gameplay unlocking several items and characters. Once you beat the heart and the fetus boss, it's time to get to beat many challenges. The prequel Isaac seemed a bit too easy and the item combinations didn't work well. Rebirth and Afterbirth got it fixed and improved. You become a killing machine with many items that synergizes with one another. While experimenting with items, you'll feel like you're chemist doing a mix work.  It is also very easy to get angry while playing this game. So that's another attribute of any other games.  11/10 would buy the second DLC if it comes out.

Simply put, The Binding of Isaac is a pillar for Indie Games & DIY devlopment. It took so many influences from various games. The level/screen progression of The Legend of Zelda, the randomness of Toe Jam & Earl and the grimy and esoteric visual style of the White Wolf published table-top game HoL (google it). Everytime you load up the game, every session will be a different experince. The continued support of the developers and replay value is something that AAA devs and publishers should really take note. This will be a game that we will be playing on our holo decks in the future generations to come.

This game is worth it for new players to Isaac or old.  Improvements over the original: -More items, cards, challenges, bosses, rooms, floors.... (everything) -Ability to save and come back later -Much better performance  The only possible downside people discuss is a few remaining bugs (at the time of writing) that do not impact gameplay heavily and will most likely be patched out soon. Music is hit or miss for people who play. The original had a very good soundtrack, and some say that Rebirth does not come close to it (it is still good).  I would highly recommend that people try this game. If the price is a deterrent since no demo is available, try the original first. The gameplay is identical, but this game does far exceed it in most other qualities.

Being a big fan of a binding of isaac, I couldn't wait for this to come out... and oh it did not dissapoint. It improved the predecessor and then some, there's more of everything, the game is so slick and going back to the original seems to be almost impossible. from my near 50 hours so far I've encountered practically no bugs compared to the original, the item combinations are great, everything is an improvement basically. Be prepared to be addicted to this as it's replay-value is quite possibly the best of any game. I showed it to one of my friends the other day and he couldn't understand it watching on, he found it 'weird'... That was until he played it himself and he was as engrossed as anyone. It's everything an indie game should be.  Buy this game, you won't regret it. 9.5/10

But this game, THIS GAME, has made me such an addict to dungeon crawlers and rpg style games that i can't get enough of them. Binding of Isaac: Rebirth, is an update to the modern classic, the Binding of Isaac, originally released in 2011. Rebirth uses a new engine with updated graphics. The art style is slightly pixlated which is different from the original, which was more smooth. The controls are tight and one can use either keyboard or controller. There is no mouse support -- even in the menus, which is unfortunate.   If you enjoyed the original Isaac, you'll probably enjoy Rebirth as well. There are new enemies, items, rooms, and challenges. Plenty to keep you engaged for hours. There are some issues with frame rate (on my PC anyway) when thre are a lot of tears or brimestone effects in a given room. Turning the 'Filter' option to OFF helps with this, although makes the game art even more pixelated.

What's more to say about this game? It's the greatest example of expanding on a formula, don't change it to change it. It adds a greatly improved engine, more items, and even more strategies that will give it legs for years and years to come. Personally in the original I pumped in over 1000 hours, and I honestly don't think I can go back to playing the original.  The gameplay is so fluid, and so much closer to a bullet hell style that It's as close to perfect as you can get. Infinite variety, item synergies, and replayability keeps me coming back over and over again.  Hard mode adds a great challenge for those making the transition to BOI from the original, and keeps the challenge at a high level.   Rebirth will be one of those games that will never leave my locally installed list of my steam client.

After racking up a good 100 hours or so on the original Binding Of Isaac it's safe to say that Rebirth is a worthy successor of the original game.  Firstly it's no longer ran on flash so even the most basic processors can run this game at good frames per second. Secondly the vast amount of new enemies, items and rooms adds even more reply value, knowing for a fact that each time to start a new run something different will happen, with a different outcome. Thirdly the soundtrack is as you would expect and is as awesome as the original.  If you enjoyed the original Binding Of Isaac I highly recommend this as it will add even more reply value than it already has. Even if you are new to dungeon crawlers or haven't played the original, this is definitely worth a shot. 8.8/10

If you're buying this for the zelda-ish aspect, you'll learn very quickly that this is much more bullet hell. This game is more like 1/6 nethack, 1/6 zelda, 1/3 bullet hell, 1/3 original. It's a lot of fun.  Literally this is the only roguelike I can just sit and play over and over and over again hours on end and not get bored. I'm very positive that even if you're looking at the wiki and trying to unlock everything, you probably need a good 100hrs to do so. And that's not even counting afterbirth, which comes out soon.  Not to mention, it's stupid. In a good, trollish, politically incorrect, hilarious and possibly even clever way. Oh, and there's a lot of crap to do. In multiple ways.  Do I recommend this? Yes. It'll probably keep you busy until Bethesda has fixed all the bugs in F4. And it'll probably end up there pretty high on your playtime list.

Pros - Well polished art style and aesthetic. - Tight gameplay mechanics. - Almost unrivalled sense of discovery when it comes to item combinations. - Great music! - Immensely replayable, always hits you with that 'just one more run' feeling.  Cons - Devil deal mechanic seems imbalanced with the Angel deal mechanic. - Could use more character variety. I know they're Isaac in different wigs, but more variation in core play mechanics between characters would have been great. Compared to just switching around starting stats and items. - Certain bosses are more frustrating than fun to fight against (Carrion Queen, Mask of Infamy).

This game is fantastic.  Its kinda hard for me to describe why I like it so much, but here goes.  I orignally played the first Binding of Isaac, and was entertained for a couple hours, but quickly got bored. With rebirth, I am still the first game I go to after 200 hours. The items and their synergies are amazing, the bosses are fantastic, the whole experience is absolutely worth every penny. Each run seems like a fresh start, but not at the expense of being boring. The runs are of decent length, and there are plenty of goals to shoot for and items to unlock to keep you interested.  The one thing I suggest is to get the dlc sooner rather than later, as it makes the game seem way more full. (however, I reccomend unlocking lost with seeds before you get the dlc, if you plan on unlocking it)  10/10 one of my favorite games of all time.

I've enjoyed this game very much, the beginning can be fairly difficult to get through and hard to unlock items, characters, floors, etc. But continuning on the game is very rewarding to see all the content this game has to offer if you continue to try again. Although there are flaws to this game like any other game, the positives outway the negatives greatly in my opinion.  Pros: - Good controls - The community is very helpful and kind people - The graphics are beautiful, lots of small details to the game - Very run has something different, so each try is a new game! - The characters are very cute - Lots of hours can be put into before boredom - The 'syngeries' between items - Large amount of content - Bosses, curses, and challenges keep this game not too easy - Beautiful soundtrack  Cons: - Bullet hell (in some scenarios) - Damage is sometimes unavoidable/very difficult to avoid - Bloat :(   Thank you for reading my review, and if I seem to have mislead in anyway or forgotten information please tell me so!!

This game will kick your teeth in then ♥♥♥♥ in your mouth. It's hard and unfair. How well you do is based on if it decides to give you good items that round and usually it doesn't. Good game.  Edit about 300 hours later----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------  I feel the need to re-evaluate my review but at the same time I feel like my primary review works for how it feels for the first 10 hours. After the game is played with a little more and things are unlocked and you're far more aware of what everything does and how you can use those systems to your advatage it becomes much easier. Or at least the normal stuff does. Then you unlock the lost and in afterbirth the keeper and the challenges get harder and harder. Well the game retains some of the brutality it does from when you first pick it up. But at least now that difficulty has been regulated to a smaller portion of the game. You start getting better and it starts getting easier. The point is the game has a good difficulty curve, and while the next step is always a little more brutal then it needs to be, with persistance it is possible and is extremely rewarding once you have reached the top. I still quite haven't but I'm on my way, and you should give it a shot too. A great game that I have spent hundreds of hours on and will spend hundreds of hours more.

Rebirth took a simple 2D flash game and made it so much more. But that doesn't mean it is perfect.  Pros: Awesome soundtrack. Difficult but rewarding gameplay. So much Replayablity. Has a lot of effort put into it. The DLC is an amazing expansion that give so much more hours of gameplay. Cons:  Recent patches have been known to make the game more unstable such as crashes. Some of the aspects of the the gameplay are pretty luck based and there is a chance of getting a run so overpowered that it removes the fun out of the game.  Some of the items in game are more overpowered than they are supposed to be such as sack boy.  The main overpowered damage dealing items (such as moms knife and brimstone) overwrites most of the other tear effects and they only have a small amount of synergies.  I have made it my goal to complete this games achievements. 10/10 would kill the lamb with a blank card / chaos card combination again.

Want 10 pentagrams? You can have it. This isn't supported, but not shamed either, so its your choice if you do it. If you are a completionist, you are in for a long game with 276 acheivements (DLC), two irritating characters (Keeper DLC, Lost), and infinite combinations. Hard, fun, and overall great, this game is worth the money.
