I've been playing this game for one year now on a regular basis (expect for a break after reaching 1001%) and up to this point it has still the charm it had at the start. If you have money to spare, then get this game because it probably will consume a LOT of your time because of the randomly generated runs. And you'll love it.  + fluent gameplay (compared to the original Binding of Isaac) + fair challenge (the game seems unfair at first but after a while, when you've learned the pattern of monsters and what item does what, you'll get easily used to each run) + 100 hours+ minimum completion time (depending on your skill Isaac Rebirth can take up to 150 hours, for some 300 hours) + useful achievements (for the completionists and achievements hunters, each achievements makes sense as you can use it as a full check list for what you have to do ingame) + mods (got bored of Isaac Rebirth / got 1001%, don't worry. There are tons of mods for that game in many categories from music changing, cosmetic changes to complete overhauls. Easy to install, easy to rack up your playing time) + daily challenges to compete with other players in highscore and finish time  - the music (this is a personal preference but after playing the Undertale mod and going back to the original Rebirth soundtrack, I started to dislike it) - reaching the final boss (it depends on quite a bunch of luck and sometimes you can play quite a lot of runs until you get the right item to open the door to the final boss. Annoying for completionists)

Of all the rogue-lite games that have been released over the last few years, few even came close to matching The Binding of Isaac, and this sequel ramps everything up to become in my view the definitive game of the genre. Packed with secrets, varied items, constant unlocks and multiple modes, there's no lack of content here.   What really elevates it above other rogue-lites for me though is that it is entirely beatable on any run with the right level of skill; so often games of this type put some wall that requires specific preparation or a bit of luck in the item draw to carry you through, but with Isaac as long as your skills are up to snuff you'll be able to win every time; of course, getting to that level is not as simple as it sounds!  Buy it, and get ready to lose an awful lot of hours.

The Binding of Isaac: Rebirth is sort of an odd game. It holds a unique slot in my gaming where, at the moment, I play at least one playthrough of it each day. It is kind of like Solitair, Peggle, or Bejeweled in a sense, in that it is a go to game for me when I have a few minutes to spare.  So what is this game? It is the dungeons of Zelda mixed with rogue-like randomization. The goal is to kill one of the final bosses by picking up items and growing in power. What makes this fun is that the items are randomized, but every playthrough is beatable. You can manipulate the randomness to do some crazy things and just break the power curve. But you can also get a bad room and loose a run in a second. The entire game doesn't take long to beat, maybe an hour? But the fun is not in that this game takes a long time, it is that the complexity unfolds as stuff is unlocked.  So what is there to unlock? There are items, charecters, and whole levels that will be added to the item pool the more you complete the game with each charecter. And even without that, there are challenge runs and greed mode. There is the daily challenge (which is a unique gametype with a unique goal sometimes). The updates add to the game without diminishing the core that is there, and there are modding tools and more updates coming. This game is the best.  The only negative, for me, is the aesthetic. The story and art style can be very disturbing and it kind of undermines the fun of the game...that said, I have got to a point in this game where I don't even notice the story or disturbing elements of the art.

Highly compulsive, endlessly rewarding, I've been forgoing AAA games sitting patiently in my library for months now whilst playing this.

Binding of Isaac: Ribirth is as good as its predecessor, with a lot more stuff and therefore a lot more various synergies between items. The game is a lot smoother than the previous one. It is really refreshing to play a game like this, although this one is not as challenging as the 'original' binding of Isaac.

This game is amazing. It is a complete recreation of the original binding of isaac, but the new engine allows for more capabilities, more items, more synergies, and actual bullet hells that don't depend on 'if, then' calculations to work. The pixelated art style, while it isn't as interesting as the original, still holds its ground. The gameplay is very smooth, and this game is the ultimate stress test. No other predicament has made my heart pound faster (this is actually true. During a crucial fight, I died at what should have been my winning point. I could literally hear my heart thrashing at the speed of a piston in a lambhourgini engine) than this game. This game, however, still manages to be a fun casual game. If there's one thing I must complain about though, it is the soundtrack. Like the graphics, it holds its ground, but the original soundtrack had emotion, fear, and had a dark feel to it. The music here is very much like ambient metal, mostly because it is. This is fine, because the metal gives the game a more 'high octane' feel, but no more than the original. All in all, 10/10, would buy three times over again.

How I wish TBofI:R was explained to me:  This game is a cute and funny dungeon crawler and it is difficult. The levels are randomly generated and you never get the same levels twice (with a standard play through). Your main weapon is a projectile. As you advance, you collect random pickups that greatly enhance or otherwise change the gameplay mechanics. A lot of items can be stacked, so you have the potential to become very powerful. The game is challenging, but every now and then you will have a run with rare items that really make Isaac (or whoever you chose to play as) into a tank. Not a real tank, but a killing machine. When you are running through the game with good items, it becomes VERY satisfying. The game has a lot of random elements, but you begin to learn how to play strategically to give yourself the best odds, There are boss battles, they are really well done. This game supports many different play styles and the re-play value is off the charts. You will never be bored.  I've never played the original Binding of Isaac, but this game is amazing. I decided to give it a go because I was born in 1990 and The Legend of Zelda was a staple of my childhood. I personally don't care much for the Roguelike genre, but I don't really think about The Binding of Isaac: Rebirth as a Roguelike game, simply because it only takes minutes from the beginning of a play to forget how upset you were that you died 45 minutes into an awesome run and are starting over with nothing.  Very addictive and very satisfying. I reccomend this game to anyone who enjoyes video games. I don't care what kind, there is something for everyone here.

Pros:   A plethora of different items to enhance your character in each playthrough   Each attempt is unique in both charcter development and room/enemy layout   Difficult and rewarding   Unlockable characters and items increase variety and replayability   The seed of the run is displayed and can be used to rerun   More accessible than the original The Binding of Isaac   Very fluid 60fps with no slowdowns   Many challenges, although they are all fairly easy   Character progression tracker   Cons:   The difficulty of a run is very reliant upon random number generation   Few item descriptions forces players to either read a wiki or risk losing runs   Rebirth feels considerably easier than the original (on normal)   No graphics options and capped at 60fps  Summary: This is is essentially The Binding of Isaac redone with more content, options, and best of all, not made on flash. While the original can be exceptionally fun and rewarding, Rebirth increases the accessibility of the game substantially while retaining most of the difficulty when set to hard. Overall, I would consider almost every aspect of Rebirth a solid upgrade over the original game. My biggest complaint is the lack of an in game method to determine what an item does before taking it (or while holding it), but after playing a good amount of the original, I already knew most of the items. If you are wondering about purchasing the original, I would highly recommend skipping it and purchasing Rebirth instead. The smooth 60fps compared to the sluggish 30fps + slowdowns of the original alone make it worth the difference. Both games have the same 'story' and Rebirth is truly a remastered (upgraded) original.  Verdict: 9.5/10

Laughing. Crying. Raging. Praying. Winning. Losing.  As a big indie fan, I have always looked forward to games published by NICALIS, and this was one I looked foward to for several months. Even though I played the original Binding of Isaac for roughly 40 hours, I still loved it nonetheless. All the mechanics that went along with it fascinated me, and I was hooked on it ever since.  When the Binding of Isaac: Rebirth first came out, I played it until I gave out. From boredom in class to casual gaming, I clocked in at exactly 41 hours my first week, already exceeding my Vanilla and Wrath of the Lamb time.  One of the major complaints I heard about the game was the soundtrack by Ridiculon. Personally, I found this soundtrack perfectly fine, and that's not to say it was any worse than Danny Baranowsky's soundtrack for the original Binding of Isaac.  At hour 173, I completed what I believe to be as the most difficult thing I've ever done in a videogame, I finally completed the requirements for (spoiler alert!) The Lost.  After 201 hours of sitting and (see verbs above), on the same day I spent 7 straight hours pressing 'R' and trying to get the f-cking Book of Revelations, I finally completed the game with the (another spoiler alert!) REAL PLATINUM GOD. Now I sit here and wait the infamous DLC: Afterbirth.   And do you know what the best part of this game is? I can accredit a pile of poop for killing me over twenty times. 11/10 - Would play again.

EDIT after testing Afterbirth content (Scroll down for Rebirth review):    The DLC upgrades the game to an estimated double content. It is compareable to the changes Millen made with the Wrath of the Lamb DLC of tBoI back in the days. On the one hand it improves the game with small but important tweaks like better graphics, new music, a new announcer, faster animations and a HUD inventory overlay option. On the other, it also integrates 2 new characters, new alternate maps, extra challenges, alot of new items to destroy more and more poop piles, more achievements to explore and 2 new playable gamemodes: Daily challenges like those in Spelunky with premade dungeons (online ladder) and Greed mode which is comparable to arena campaigns and very nice new bosses and less roaming. This will lead to another potential 200 hrs of playtime, love it!  All in all, this update is definitely worth buying. It ups my vanilla version rating from 10 to 11/10.     Rebirth review    Why play any other single player game if there's The Binding of Isaac: Rebirth?!? 10/10, most of the players already know why. ;) It's perfect in all aspects but still lacking an online multiplayer gamemode, which is the only downside. Ignore the couch coop promise, it's not a real coop but 1 player supports the other as a brother/sister companion. If you haven't played it yet, do so! You haven't played any soloplay indie title yet that is superior to this, believe me! Unlimited replay value.  me = hooked  P.S.: I love you, Mr. McMillen, a fanboy! XD

If you're like me, a big fan of Edmund McMillen and Roguelikes, there's a chance you may still find this game fun after 400 hours like I did and therefore should totally buy it.  If you liked Spelunky, Super meat boy, the orginal Legend of Zelda or VVVVVV, I'm pretty sure you won't regret your purchase for this game.  this game requires dedication.  If you're NOT like me and you wanna stay on a budget when it's not on sale and think you'll only play it for a few hours, just get the original Binding of Isaac for $5 on full price.  Then, if you find out you actually love this game then don't hesitate to buy Rebirth with the DLC. This game is the original Binding of Isaac X 666. You liked the ♥♥♥♥ed up themes? Have even more ♥♥♥♥ed up themes, you liked the randomness?then have even more randomness. You liked the items, the bosses, the areas and secrets? Then have a lot more of that. you fell in love with the amount of poop in the older game? Well have EVEN MOOOORE POOP ! Also, that's not even mentioning the DLC and knowing there's ANOTHER DLC on it's way with modding tools.  tl;dr: if you didn't try the original game, try it. From the meaty boys that brought you 'Super Meat Boy' comes the tale of a tiny baby-man who, like most other infants, generally minds his own damn business. This behaviour is supposedly noticed by god himself who seeks to bring wrath to his heretical ways. God convenes with the child's mother and together they decide the most logical course of action is to murder the infant to death.  The story follows baby Isaac as he bundies through mum's basement in an attempt to escape the clutches of his ever so slightly looney but also very insane mother. The creatures of the basement are none too happy about Isaac's arrival and see to handing him over to the proper authorities. Isaac, in turn, seeks to win them over by crying with the grace and mercy of an M32 grenade launcher.  While Isaac's tears are godlike on their own there are LITERALLY hundreds of upgrades for every situation both in and out of the playbook. On average, a newborn in this game can present twenty times more of a threat than unattended baggage at an airport and can perform every function a baby would otherwise perform at an olympic level.  Isaac and his compadres can: - Cry tears in every direction at once.  - Bathe their enemies in fire and nuerotoxins.  - Utilise psionic powers to alter the flight path of tears. - Ruin perfectly functional walls with explosions. - Communicate with the devil. - Spout torrents of blood that pierce flesh and stone alike. - Use currency to obtain goods. - Poo and/or turn their enemies into poo. - Cry thermonuclear payloads.  And that's just page one...   If you enjoy crying as much as I do then the Binding of Isaac is sure to put a slightly bemused smile on your face.
